title: Why did hospitals have these frogs in their supply rooms? - Carly Anne York

multiple-choice.question: What species of frog was used for pregnancy testing from the 1930s to the 1960s?

options.label: A
options.text: American bullfrog

options.label: B
options.text: African clawed frog

options.label: C
options.text: European common frog

options.label: D
options.text: Australian green tree frog

multiple-choice.question: Describe the primary adaptation of the African clawed frog.

options.label: A
options.text: They have developed strong hind legs for jumping.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a long tongue for catching prey.

options.label: C
options.text: They are almost exclusively aquatic, adapted for swimming.

options.label: D
options.text: They have a thick skin to prevent water loss.

multiple-choice.question: A researcher wants to study the developmental biology of amphibians. Which characteristic of the African clawed frog makes it an ideal model for this study?

options.label: A
options.text: Their slow development and seasonal egg production

options.label: B
options.text: Their rapid development and ability to produce eggs in any season

options.label: C
options.text: Their complex nervous system and brain structure

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to change color for camouflage

multiple-choice.question: What was the role of the pituitary gland in the African clawed frog's color-changing mechanism, as discovered by the trio of biologists in South Africa?

options.label: A
options.text: The pituitary gland produced a hormone that triggered color change.

options.label: B
options.text: The pituitary gland had no effect on the color-changing mechanism.

options.label: C
options.text: Removing the pituitary gland impaired the frog's ability to camouflage.

options.label: D
options.text: The pituitary gland produced a hormone that prevented color change.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the ox hormone injected into the African clawed frogs by Lancelot Hogben?

options.label: A
options.text: It triggered their ovulation without the presence of a male.

options.label: B
options.text: It impaired their ability to camouflage.

options.label: C
options.text: It had no effect on the frogs.

options.label: D
options.text: It caused them to release eggs only when a male was nearby.

multiple-choice.question: How did the use of African clawed frogs improve pregnancy testing compared to previous methods?

options.label: A
options.text: The test was more expensive and time-consuming.

options.label: B
options.text: The test required multiple days of injections and dissection.

options.label: C
options.text: The test was faster, with results in roughly 9 hours, and did not require dissection.

options.label: D
options.text: The test was less accurate and reliable.

multiple-choice.question: Why were African clawed frogs eventually replaced by chemical tests for pregnancy detection?

options.label: A
options.text: The frogs were too expensive to maintain and ship.

options.label: B
options.text: The chemical tests were more accurate and reliable.

options.label: C
options.text: The frogs were becoming extinct due to overcollection.

options.label: D
options.text: The chemical tests were able to detect hCG directly, making them more efficient.

multiple-choice.question: What is a negative consequence of the widespread use of African clawed frogs in scientific research?

options.label: A
options.text: They have helped to increase the population of native amphibians.

options.label: B
options.text: They have contributed to the development of new medicines.

options.label: C
options.text: They have carried a deadly fungus that has devastated amphibian populations.

options.label: D
options.text: They have improved our understanding of the ecosystem.

multiple-choice.question: Evaluate the overall impact of using African clawed frogs in scientific research.

options.label: A
options.text: The benefits of using African clawed frogs in research outweigh the drawbacks.

options.label: B
options.text: The drawbacks of using African clawed frogs in research outweigh the benefits.

options.label: C
options.text: The use of African clawed frogs in research has had both positive and negative results.

options.label: D
options.text: The use of African clawed frogs in research has had no significant impact.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current classification of the African clawed frog due to its impact on native ecosystems?

options.label: A
options.text: Endangered species

options.label: B
options.text: Invasive species

options.label: C
options.text: Vulnerable species

options.label: D
options.text: Least concern species

title: Why is this black square famous? - Allison Leigh

multiple-choice.question: Where did the exhibition of radical artworks, featuring Kazimir Malevich's "Black Square," take place in 1915?

options.label: A
options.text: Moscow, Russia

options.label: B
options.text: St. Petersburg, Russia

options.label: C
options.text: Ukraine

options.label: D
options.text: Poland

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial reaction of some attendees to Malevich's "Black Square" at the exhibition?

options.label: A
options.text: They praised its simplicity and innovative style

options.label: B
options.text: They were indifferent to the painting

options.label: C
options.text: They scoffed at its simplicity, claiming a child could have done it

options.label: D
options.text: They immediately recognized its significance in the art world

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the central form in Malevich's "Black Square"?

options.label: A
options.text: It is perfectly black and perfectly square

options.label: B
options.text: It is neither perfectly black nor perfectly square, with uneven sides and an off-center placement

options.label: C
options.text: It is a representation of a real-world object

options.label: D
options.text: It is a collaborative work with another artist

multiple-choice.question: What does the presence of craquelure in the painting reveal?

options.label: A
options.text: The painting's age and the materials used

options.label: B
options.text: The artist's lack of skill and technique

options.label: C
options.text: The influence of other art movements on Malevich's work

options.label: D
options.text: The initial negative reactions to the painting

multiple-choice.question: How did Malevich's creative process influence the final form of "Black Square"?

options.label: A
options.text: He carefully planned and executed the painting to achieve a precise, geometric shape

options.label: B
options.text: He went through multiple stages, experimenting with different colors and techniques, before arriving at the final form

options.label: C
options.text: He was inspired by a single, defining moment or experience

options.label: D
options.text: He sought to replicate the style of another artist

multiple-choice.question: What was the core idea behind Malevich's Suprematist movement?

options.label: A
options.text: To create art that accurately represented everyday life

options.label: B
options.text: To focus on the emotional and expressive qualities of art

options.label: C
options.text: To develop a new style of abstract art

options.label: D
options.text: To make art that was accessible to a wider audience

multiple-choice.question: How did Malevich's work change after Stalin's rise to power in the 1920s?

options.label: A
options.text: He continued to produce avant-garde, Suprematist works

options.label: B
options.text: He adapted his style to conform to the enforced Socialist Realism

options.label: C
options.text: He abandoned art altogether

options.label: D
options.text: He went into exile to continue creating freely

multiple-choice.question: What subtle detail in Malevich's later self-portrait hinted at his continued connection to Suprematism?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of a red star

options.label: B
options.text: The depiction of a hammer and sickle

options.label: C
options.text: The formation of a quadrilateral by his open hand

options.label: D
options.text: The absence of any symbolic elements

multiple-choice.question: How did Malevich's experience of wars and revolutions influence his artistic vision?

options.label: A
options.text: It led him to focus on creating art that was more representational and accessible

options.label: B
options.text: It strengthened his commitment to creating a new, pure art that transcended the suffering of the world

options.label: C
options.text: It caused him to abandon his artistic pursuits

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on his work

multiple-choice.question: What was the ultimate goal of Malevich's Suprematist movement, and how did he aim to achieve it?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a new, representational art that celebrated the Soviet state, through careful planning and execution

options.label: B
options.text: To develop a non-objective, non-representational art that made feeling supreme, through simplification and distortion

options.label: C
options.text: To produce art that was accessible to a wider audience, by adapting to popular styles

options.label: D
options.text: To reject the idea of art as a means of expression, in favor of a more utilitarian approach

title: What the fossil fuel industry doesn't want you to know - Al Gore

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main concern regarding the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: The crisis is not solvable.

options.label: B
options.text: The crisis will not be solved in time.

options.label: C
options.text: The crisis is not a major issue.

options.label: D
options.text: The crisis has already been solved.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Inflation Reduction Act in the United States?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the smallest climate legislation in history.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the best and biggest climate legislation in history.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on climate change.

options.label: D
options.text: It only focuses on reducing inflation.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the primary obstacle to addressing the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of technology.

options.label: B
options.text: Unrelenting opposition from the fossil fuel industry.

options.label: C
options.text: Insufficient funding.

options.label: D
options.text: Limited public awareness.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a proven and effective solution.

options.label: B
options.text: It is still in development and not yet feasible.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not necessary for addressing climate change.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only useful for oil companies.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's opinion on the fossil fuel industry's commitment to reducing emissions?

options.label: A
options.text: They are sincere actors working in good faith.

options.label: B
options.text: They are driven by incentives that push them in the opposite direction.

options.label: C
options.text: They are only interested in making a profit.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not capable of reducing emissions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the COP process in addressing climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a crucial platform for international cooperation.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a hindrance to progress due to the influence of fossil fuel companies.

options.label: C
options.text: It is only relevant for developed countries.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not necessary for addressing climate change.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the impact of subsidies for fossil fuels?

options.label: A
options.text: They support the transition to renewable energy.

options.label: B
options.text: They hinder the transition to renewable energy.

options.label: C
options.text: They have no impact on the transition to renewable energy.

options.label: D
options.text: They are necessary for economic growth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on the potential for renewable energy to address climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not a viable solution.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a crucial part of the solution, but not enough on its own.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the only solution needed to address climate change.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not necessary for addressing climate change.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the potential outcome if the world reaches true net-zero emissions?

options.label: A
options.text: Global temperatures will continue to rise.

options.label: B
options.text: Global temperatures will stop going up with a lag time of 3-5 years.

options.label: C
options.text: The ice will stop melting immediately.

options.label: D
options.text: The CO2 in the atmosphere will increase.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to the audience regarding the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: We should give up hope and accept the inevitable.

options.label: B
options.text: We should be vulnerable to despair and doubt our ability to act.

options.label: C
options.text: We should not be vulnerable to despair and have the will to act.

options.label: D
options.text: We should ignore the crisis and focus on other issues.

title: Can you change your sleep schedule?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the nerve cell clusters located in the anterior hypothalamus?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate body temperature

options.label: B
options.text: To track the day-night cycle and dictate the body's internal clock

options.label: C
options.text: To manage hormone production

options.label: D
options.text: To control organ functioning

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of melatonin in the circadian system?

options.label: A
options.text: To induce wakefulness

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate body temperature

options.label: C
options.text: To prepare the body for sleep

options.label: D
options.text: To manage hormone production

multiple-choice.question: A person consistently goes to sleep at 11 pm. When is their circadian system likely to start producing sleep-inducing melatonin?

options.label: A
options.text: 9 pm

options.label: B
options.text: 10 pm

options.label: C
options.text: 11 pm

options.label: D
options.text: 12 am

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of unpredictable sleeping habits on the circadian system, according to research on sleep-deprived college students?

options.label: A
options.text: It strengthens the circadian system

options.label: B
options.text: It has no impact on the circadian system

options.label: C
options.text: It weakens the entire circadian system

options.label: D
options.text: It only affects hormone production

multiple-choice.question: Why is getting sufficient contrast between bright daylight and dimmer nighttime light essential for the circadian rhythm?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate body temperature

options.label: B
options.text: To manage hormone production

options.label: C
options.text: To synchronize the circadian rhythm

options.label: D
options.text: To control organ functioning

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of keeping consistent sleeping hours for the circadian system?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps the body adapt to changing sleep schedules

options.label: B
options.text: It allows the body to sleep in later

options.label: C
options.text: It helps the body accurately predict when to send out hormones

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on the circadian system

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between the cortisol peaks of early birds and night owls?

options.label: A
options.text: Early birds peak cortisol levels 30 minutes after waking, while night owls peak just before waking

options.label: B
options.text: Early birds peak cortisol levels just before waking, while night owls peak 30 minutes after waking

options.label: C
options.text: Early birds have higher cortisol levels than night owls

options.label: D
options.text: Night owls have higher cortisol levels than early birds

multiple-choice.question: What is the likely outcome of trying to maintain a sleep schedule that pushes against the body's preferences?

options.label: A
options.text: The body will adapt to the new schedule

options.label: B
options.text: The circadian system will be strengthened

options.label: C
options.text: It will be difficult to maintain, and one bad night can send the circadian system back to baseline

options.label: D
options.text: The body will experience no negative effects

multiple-choice.question: What is the most important factor in determining a healthy sleep schedule, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Waking up at a specific time

options.label: B
options.text: Going to sleep at a specific time

options.label: C
options.text: Getting enough rest for the day ahead

options.label: D
options.text: Following a strict schedule

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of compromised circadian rhythms on overall health, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to improved immune function

options.label: B
options.text: It can lead to improved metabolic function

options.label: C
options.text: It can incur health risks like metabolic disorders and vulnerable immune systems

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on overall health

title: Does COVID mess with your DNA?

multiple-choice.question: What is long COVID, and how is it defined?

options.label: A
options.text: A condition that occurs immediately after COVID-19 infection and lasts for 1-2 weeks.

options.label: B
options.text: A condition that occurs 4 weeks to 3 months after COVID-19 infection and has devastating effects on quality of life.

options.label: C
options.text: A condition that occurs only in older adults and is characterized by mild symptoms.

options.label: D
options.text: A condition that is caused by a different virus than COVID-19.

multiple-choice.question: What is epigenetics, and how does it relate to gene expression?

options.label: A
options.text: Epigenetics is the study of genetic mutations and their effects on gene expression.

options.label: B
options.text: Epigenetics is the study of how environmental factors affect gene expression.

options.label: C
options.text: Epigenetics is the study of how cells modulate genetic information without changing the DNA sequence.

options.label: D
options.text: Epigenetics is the study of how viruses affect gene expression.

multiple-choice.question: What is DNA methylation, and how does it affect gene expression?

options.label: A
options.text: DNA methylation is a process that adds a tag to a gene to increase its expression.

options.label: B
options.text: DNA methylation is a process that adds a tag to a gene to decrease its expression.

options.label: C
options.text: DNA methylation is a process that removes a tag from a gene to increase its expression.

options.label: D
options.text: DNA methylation is a process that removes a tag from a gene to decrease its expression.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what did researchers find in a study on DNA methylation in patients with long COVID?

options.label: A
options.text: They found no changes in DNA methylation.

options.label: B
options.text: They found changes in DNA methylation that persisted after infection, but only in a few genes.

options.label: C
options.text: They found changes in DNA methylation that persisted after infection, including genes involved in regulating ACE2 and histamine signaling.

options.label: D
options.text: They found changes in DNA methylation that were only present during acute COVID-19 infection.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential link between long COVID and chronic fatigue syndrome, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Patients with long COVID are more likely to develop chronic fatigue syndrome.

options.label: B
options.text: Patients with chronic fatigue syndrome are more likely to develop long COVID.

options.label: C
options.text: Both conditions share similar epigenetic changes and self-antibodies.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no link between the two conditions.

multiple-choice.question: If a patient has long COVID, what might be a potential benefit of identifying genes with changed methylation patterns?

options.label: A
options.text: It could help diagnose long COVID more easily.

options.label: B
options.text: It could help treat long COVID by targeting specific genes.

options.label: C
options.text: It could help prevent long COVID from occurring in the first place.

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and B.

multiple-choice.question: Why might the findings of the Swedish study on DNA methylation in patients with long COVID be considered preliminary?

options.label: A
options.text: The study had a large sample size.

options.label: B
options.text: The study had a small sample size.

options.label: C
options.text: The study found no changes in DNA methylation.

options.label: D
options.text: The study only looked at patients with mild symptoms.

multiple-choice.question: What might be a potential explanation for the increase in cardiovascular events following COVID-19, according to the US-based research group?

options.label: A
options.text: The pattern of gene expression found in patients with long COVID.

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of self-antibodies to ACE2.

options.label: C
options.text: The persistence of DNA methylation changes after infection.

options.label: D
options.text: The development of chronic fatigue syndrome.

multiple-choice.question: How do cells decide which genes to use and when, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Cells use all genes equally and simultaneously.

options.label: B
options.text: Cells use a random selection of genes.

options.label: C
options.text: Cells use a textbook-like system, where important sections are referenced more often.

options.label: D
options.text: Cells use a lock-and-key system, where specific genes are unlocked by specific signals.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript, and why is it important?

options.label: A
options.text: The main idea is that COVID-19 is no longer a significant threat, and it's time to move on.

options.label: B
options.text: The main idea is that long COVID is a serious condition that affects many people, and research is underway to understand its causes and develop treatments.

options.label: C
options.text: The main idea is that epigenetics is a new field of study that holds the key to understanding all diseases.

options.label: D
options.text: The main idea is that DNA methylation is the only important factor in gene expression.

title: The one thing stopping jellyfish from taking over - Mariela Pajuelo & Javier Antonio Quinones

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated weight of jellyfish that a 500-kilogram leatherback sea turtle needs to eat daily to maintain a healthy weight?

options.text: 100 kilograms

options.label: B
options.text: 200 kilograms

options.label: C
options.text: 400 kilograms

options.label: D
options.text: 600 kilograms

options.text: They have a longer lifespan than adult fish

options.label: B
options.text: They consume the resources adult fish need to survive

options.label: C

title: Can alligators survive this apex predator? - Kenny Coogan

options.text: Yellowstone National Park

options.label: B
options.text: Everglades National Park

options.label: C
options.text: Yosemite National Park

options.label: D
options.text: Grand Canyon National Park

options.label: B
options.text: They create pathways and clear vegetation.

options.label: C

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Remove all non-native species and restore the original ecosystem.

options.label: C
options.text: Implement measures to prevent further invasions and control existing invasive populations.

options.label: D
options.text: Allow the ecosystem to adapt naturally without human intervention.

options.label: A
options.text: Marjory Stoneman Douglas

options.label: B
options.text: Jane Goodall

options.label: C
options.text: Rachel Carson

options.label: D
options.text: Aldo Leopold

How did the development of Florida as a major port contribute to the biodiversity of the Everglades region?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to the extinction of native species.

options.label: B
options.text: It introduced new invasive species through human and non-human migration.

options.label: C
options.text: It had no impact on the region's biodiversity.

options.label: D
options.text: It reduced the population of alligators.

options.label: A
options.text: Brazilian peppertree

options.label: B
options.text: Mangrove tree

options.label: C
options.text: Cypress tree

options.label: D
options.text: Pine tree

options.label: A
options.text: The introduction of new predators that compete with alligators for food.

options.label: B
options.text: The creation of new habitats for native species.

options.label: C
options.text: The disruption of the food chain and potential extinction of native species.

options.label: D
options.text: The improvement of water quality in the region.

multiple-choice.question: Evaluate the effectiveness of introducing new species to control invasive populations in the Everglades. What are the potential risks and benefits of this approach?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a proven method with no risks and many benefits.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a complex approach with potential risks and benefits that require careful consideration.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a simple solution with minimal risks and significant benefits.

options.label: D

options.text: It allowed them to navigate cold waters and attack prey with bursts of speed.

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the conservation implications of the decline of apex predators like megalodons?

options.text: It has no impact on the ecosystem.

options.label: B
options.text: It can lead to an increase in the population of their prey species.

options.label: C
options.text: It can destabilize entire ecosystems.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about the impact of megalodons on the evolution of marine mammals?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: 1816: The year with no summer - David Biello

multiple-choice.question: What was the date of the massive eruption of Mount Tambora in present-day Indonesia?

options.label: A
options.text: April 10th, 1810

options.label: B
options.text: April 10th, 1815

options.label: C
options.text: April 10th, 1820

options.label: D
options.text: April 10th, 1825

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary effect of the sulfurous plumes of steam and ash from Mount Tambora's eruption on the global climate?

options.label: A
options.text: It caused a significant increase in global temperatures.

options.label: B
options.text: It had no impact on global climate.

options.label: C
options.text: It blocked out the sun, leading to cold weather and famine.

options.label: D
options.text: It only affected the local climate in Indonesia.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the class of deliberate, large-scale interventions in Earth's natural systems intended to help restrain climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: Geoengineering

options.label: B
options.text: Solar Radiation Management

options.label: C
options.text: Climate Change Mitigation

options.label: D
options.text: Environmental Engineering

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a geoengineering proposal that aims to enhance natural cooling systems?

options.label: A
options.text: Building a giant sunshade in Earth's orbit

options.label: B
options.text: Enlarging marine clouds to reflect more sunlight

options.label: C
options.text: Creating a helpful version of volcanic plumes

options.label: D
options.text: Reducing greenhouse gas emissions

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential risk associated with solar radiation management as a method of geoengineering?

options.label: A
options.text: It may cause a rapid decrease in global temperatures.

options.label: B
options.text: It may lead to unpredictable ripple effects and extreme weather events.

options.label: C
options.text: It may have no impact on global climate.

options.label: D
options.text: It may be too expensive to implement.

multiple-choice.question: Why do some researchers believe that studying geoengineering is necessary, despite its risks?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a proven method of reversing climate change.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it may be civilization's last resort in desperate times.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a cost-effective solution to climate change.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it has no potential risks or side effects.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an unintended geoengineering project that has been occurring for centuries?

options.label: A
options.text: The burning of fossil fuels and resulting greenhouse gas emissions.

options.label: B
options.text: The creation of volcanic plumes to cool the planet.

options.label: C
options.text: The building of giant sunshades in Earth's orbit.

options.label: D
options.text: The enlargement of marine clouds to reflect more sunlight.

multiple-choice.question: What could happen if a geoengineering scheme, such as solar radiation management, were to be stopped abruptly after being implemented for several decades?

options.label: A
options.text: Global temperatures would continue to decrease.

options.label: B
options.text: Global temperatures would remain stable.

options.label: C
options.text: Global temperatures would rapidly rebound, causing intense super warming.

options.label: D
options.text: Global temperatures would be unaffected.

multiple-choice.question: What is a reason why some scientists are interested in using sulfurous haze to block out the sun, despite the potential risks?

options.label: A
options.text: To replicate the famine and despair of the year without summer.

options.label: B
options.text: To slow the effects of global warming.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a helpful version of volcanic plumes.

options.label: D
options.text: To build a giant sunshade in Earth's orbit.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of studying geoengineering, even if it is not implemented?

options.label: A
options.text: It may provide a solution to climate change.

options.label: B
options.text: It may help us prepare for the possibility of rogue actors implementing geoengineering without governmental approval.

options.label: C
options.text: It may prove that geoengineering is too expensive to implement.

options.label: D
options.text: It may show that geoengineering has no potential risks or side effects.
